Trial_Design.evidence: A total of 30 patients (mean ejection fraction 35%± 15%, mean QRS 119 ± 24 ms) underwent coronary bypass and/or valve surgery.

Intervention.evidence: Optimized biventricular pacing was finally compared with atrial pacing at a matched heart rate and to a sinus rhythm during 30-second intervals.

Objective.evidence: To assess the possible sustained benefit, we reviewed in the present study the effects of biventricular pacing on the mean arterial pressure after chest closure.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The mean arterial pressure was maximized during biventricular pacing using atrioventricular delays of 90 to 270 ms and interventricular delays of+80 to−80 ms during 20-second intervals in random sequence.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 30 patients (mean ejection fraction 35%± 15%, mean QRS 119 ± 24 ms) underwent coronary bypass and/or valve surgery.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Optimized biventricular pacing increased the mean arterial pressure 4% versus sinus rhythm (78.5 ± 2.4 vs 75.1 ± 2.4 mm Hg; P = .002) and 3% versus atrial pacing (76.4 ± 2.7 mm Hg; P = .017).
